body.p: The major weakness of the L.D.S. - M.Y.S in its work was not the fact that the M. Y. was lax in its work, but rather that its work had been subjected to non-constructive criticism and that the Midwest Youth Committee did not receive the cooperation of the entire L.D.S membership. While the report of the Midwest Youth Comittee could record excellent activity in the way of branch socials and sports, it indicated laxity in dramatics and the failure to develop girls' sports.

Methods of popularizing the L. D. S. were emphasized and the merit system, popularity contests and branch "sweaters" were cited as splendid mediums for advertising the L. D. S. youth branches. To better popularize the L. D. S. youth organizations in the Midwest
enlargement of the Vilnis English section it was suggested to increase it to eight pages.
Report of Sports Activity.
A review of the branch and inter-branch sports was presented in the report of Tex Zebraitis, M. Y. C. sports director.

The chief obstacle in organizing a better sports movement in the
Midwest L. D. S. branches, the report showed, was lack of proper
sports leadership, the poor response on the part of many members to
participate in sports and the difficulty of getting each branch to
participate in inter-branch sports. As a means of remedying this
fault, it was suggested that L. D. S. branches get over their apathy
toward sports members and make possible for youths to come into the
L. D. S. as sports members. Eventually these sports members could
be signed as insurance members.

While recognizing these shortcomings, the report also registered
several accomplishments.

The outstanding sport success of the year was the carrying through
of the basketball league which was not only a financial and moral
success, but was effective in attracting many outside youth to the
L. D. S. Excellent response to swimming and hiking was reported, and
this phase of activity should be encouraged.

To broaden the sports activities, the establishment of a sports center
was proposed. Such a sports center would enable members to get together
in their idle moments and participate in ping-pong, boxing and wrestling
and would attract numerous youths to the L. D. S.
Branch Reports.

Much interest was manifested by the delegates in the reports of the .
branches, primarily because those reports brought out clearly the
mistakes of the branches and valuable proposals for improving and
building the E. D. S. in the Midwest.

The report of the delegate from the Sparks reflected that the reason
the Sparks conducted short and orderly meetings was because the order
of business was worked out before the meeting, by the executive committee. This executive committee often meets three times a month to
straighten out problems which face the branch. This method of arranging
the branch meetings has resulted in improving the activity of the
branch and has allowed time for the development of new activity.

In the field of new activity the Sparks are taking the first step, as
the organization of a dramatic group indicates. The branch has already
conducted a Mock Trial and has selected 14 plays from which will be
chosen a play to be presented by the branch at a later date.

This dramatic group is opening up new opportunities for enlistment
of members and has improved the attendance at meetings.
In reporting on the progress of the drive, the Sparks' delegate cited
the signing of eleven new members and listed many prospects.
Redwings' Report.

The Redwings' report given by Nancy Gordon listed a total of 12 new
members signed during the present drive. This is one of the most
active branches in Chicago and its many varied activities include
sports, socials, hikes and bowling. Two of the main weaknesses of
the branch are the lowered level of educational activities and the
failure of the girls to participate in sports due to lack of time.
To interest the girls in sports a bicycle club has been suggested.
Monarchs' Report.

The Marquette Park Monarchs, who at one time were the monarchs of
the Chicago L. D. S. branches, reported laxity of sports activity
and lack of interest of membership in sports. To iron out these
shortcomings the Monarchs are signing sports members to stimulate
interest in sports.

Report of Roseland L. D. S. activities by Wally Unaris, showed lack
of interest by the membership to undertake new projects, but despite
this the branch has enlarged its membership by five.

The Kenosha delegate stated that the leadership in Kenosha considered
the formation of a L. D. S. youth branch separate from the adult branch
branch too lightly. There are splendid possibilities in Kenosha, but
more seriousness is necessary on the part of L. D. S. youth leaders
to build a youth branch.

English Section Report. The editor of the Vilnis' English Section
pointed out that the V. E. S. is an excellent means through which the
L. D. S. can grow. He emphasized that in order to fulfill the function
of bringing more youths into our branches it must be utilized to the
fullest extent. Branch correspondents were encouraged to contribute
regularly and encourage other youth to write stories, poetry and
articles pertaining to young people. Besides this, the columns of
the V. E. S. can be used to excellent advantage to conduct discussion
of certain phases of L. D. S. activity.

Educational Report. Jessie Shaiko reported that educational projects
at meetings have been neglected because of lengthy business meetings.
This can readily be overcome as soon as the branches learn to conduct
shorter business meetings.

As a means of making the educational part of the meeting more interesting,
debates were suggested.

To better equip our membership with the knowledge of the L. D. S. and to develop youth leaders an L. D. S. training school was suggested. The L. D. S. school to hold classes in the evening to enable better attendance.

After these remarks had been concluded a new form of L. D. S - M. Y. C. was suggested and discussed. The new committee, as was agreed on by the conference, will be composed of five regularly elected members and three alternates and three members from the executive committees of each branch. It is expected that this work of the Midwest Youth Committee will provide better leaders in and guidance to the information of committees which will facilitate the work of individual branches.
From this summary can be gathered many valuable suggestions for the improvement of our L. D. S. youth branches.
There have been many problems raised and many suggestions offered. This growth of our L. D. S. in the Midwest depends upon the extent to which we apply the proposals of this conference.
Wally Unaris.
